newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Iraq's deputy prime minister in Moscow for talks.
newsitem.headline: Iraq's deputy prime minister in Moscow for talks.

text.p: Iraqi Deputy Prime Minister Tareq Aziz arrived in Moscow on Thursday for a brief visit on his way home from a trip to China, the Iraqi Embassy said.
Aziz, anxious to bolster world support to lift sanctions imposed by the United Nations on Baghdad after it invaded Kuwait in 1990, has found a sympathetic ear in Moscow on past visits.
"He will very probably have talks in the Russian Foreign Ministry tomorrow," said ministry spokesman Valery Nesterushkin.

"The talks will certainly touch on fulfilling the Security Council humanitarian Resolution 986 and on Iraqi cooperation with the U.N. Special Commission on disarmament as well as a series of bilateral issues," he told a news briefing.
U.N. sanctions bar Baghdad's oil exports until the U.N. Special Commission -- the body in charge of disarming Iraq -- testifies that Baghdad has no more weapons of mass destruction.
But the U.N. in December allowed Iraq to sell $2 billion worth of oil over six months to buy food and medicine.
U.N. Secretary General Kofi Annan has said he expects the Security Council to renew the sale before June. Iraq is lobbying for $4 billion in oil sales, double its previous limit.
Russia has been a major buyer of oil under the plan, and the Foreign Ministry said it expected to continue the cooperation.
"We are oriented toward developing cooperation, but along with the fulfilment of the relevant U.N. resolutions," Nesterushkin said.

Russia has been stepping up efforts to improve ties in Asia and the Middle East, partially as a counterbalance to NATO plans to invite new members in eastern Europe. Moscow is also anxious to further cooperation with Iraq in oil development projects.
